doc.title: Industry View
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/U.S. Software Raimos Roundup IGV Index Not Perfect Fit For Software Performance AnymoreU.S. Software Raimos Roundup IGV _2025-08-29

passages.text: Historically, we have been using the IGV index as a good way to track performance in our space. However, a closer look shows that there is a meaningful discrepancy between what is really going on in software and the IGV performance due to current higher weightings to some of the perceived AI winners

Klaviyo told employees (link) that it is restructuring its R&D team, which includes laying off less than 100 employees with future plans to replace most of them with new hires focused on AI and technical skills (to support product development / engineering capabilities).

Microsoft announced changes to its investor disclosures this week (see here), most notably removing M365 Consumer subscribers, while leaving the rest unchanged. Additionally, we update our model to reflect disclosures post earnings. We maintain our PT of \(\) 625\(on a CY26 P/E multiple of 38x and EPS of\) \ \(16.65\) (was \(\) 16.72\$

We update our CoreWeave model following earnings. We maintain our PT of \(\) 140\(, now based on a 54x CY26E EV/EBIT multiple (was\) 55x) and CY26E EBIT of \(\) 2.05bn\((was\) \ \(2.07bn\) ). Our lower multiple reflects less debt financing in FY26.
Adobe international tiering went into effect Aug 1, and we think total (NA + Intl.) opportunity is \(\) 500M\$

On Tuesday, MongoDB reported better than consensus results with Atlas growth accelerating for the second consecutive quarter, and also beat in profitability and cash flow. nCino reported better Q2 revenue driven by overages from higher mortgage volumes. Okta beat 2Q cRPO driven by healthy US Fed and raised the FY revenue guide, removing incremental conservatism from macro & publisher sector.

On Wednesday, Snowflake reported strong Q2 results, highlighted by a 5% product revenue beat that marks the largest q/q add in company history and raised FY guidance above the Q2 beat level. Veeva beat and raised billings expectations drive by strength in Crossix and a firmer R&p pipeline. CrowdStrike beat our upside scenario for 2Q net new ARR and guided to a \(\sim 22\%\) ARR exit rate for FY26.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 16. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 03:14 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 04:00 GMT Restricted - External
U.S. Software POSITIVE Unchanged

Sprout Social announced that co- founder Aaron Rankin is terminating his prior stock plan and is initiating a new plan for future stock purchases, citing that the stock is "undervalued" with CEO Ryan Barreto building a similar plan.
Today, August 29th, at 11am ET, software analysts Raimo Lenschow and Saket Kalia will be hosting our biweekly investor call.
On Wednesday, September 2nd, Zscaler reports earnings after the close.

On Wednesday, September 3rd, Sprinklr reports earnings before the open. Salesforce and GitLab report earnings after the close. HubSpot will also be hosting its INBOUND Conference and Analyst Day on Wednesday, September 3rd.
On Thursday, September 4th, Braze and UiPath report earnings after the close.
Summary of our Ratings, Price Targets and Earnings Changes in this Report (all changes are shown in bold)

Source: Barclays Research. Share prices and target prices are shown in the primary listing currency and EPS estimates are shown in the reporting currency. FY1(E): Current fiscal year estimates by Barclays Research. FY2(E): Next fiscal year estimates by Barclays Research. Stock Rating: OW: Overweight; EW: Equal Weight; UW: Underweight; RS: Rating Suspended Industry View: Pos: Positive; Neu: Neutral; Neg: Negative.

Valuation Methodology: We apply a 54x CY26E EV/EBIT multiple to our EBIT estimate of \(\) 2.05bn\(to arrive at our PT of\) \ \(140\) . As part of our EV build, we assume 2026E net debt of \(\) 29.8bn\$

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks to our investment thesis include increasing competition across the Al- optimized laaS space, inhibiting both existing customer growth as well as new customer contribution. With new players building out full functionality for Al- laaS, CoreWeave's market leading position could be challenged. Additionally, critical customers like Microsoft, which are also building competing solutions, could bring more of their Al laaS in house, which would have an impact on CoreWeave's growth outlook on a go forward. Lastly, any impact to the global supply chain as a result of uncertainty could result in timing delays for CoreWeaves CapEx, which would inhibit the company's ability to build out infrastructure for customers on a go forward.

Valuation Methodology: Our PT of \(\) 625\$ is based on P/E multiple of 38x and CY26E EPS of \(\) 16.65\$ . Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The emergence of cloud computing, virtualization and new non- PC form factors such as tablets and smart phones represent ongoing risks to Microsoft's business model and underlying profitability. Increased investment spend in long- term growth initiatives such as search and mobile could also cause margins to come under significant pressure.
Source: Barclays Research

At face value, the IGV index would imply that software has not performed that poorly this year with the IGV up around \(9\%\) year to date compared to the S&P up \(10.5\%\) , and Nasdaq up \(13\%\) . However, we are not sure that the IGV paints a fully accurate picture.

The IGV (expanded Tech- Software Sector ETF) is supposed to mirror the performance of the S&P North American Expanded Technology Software Index and it is doing a decent job there with only a small discrepancy. The issue here is the composition of the index.

In theory, we could just use the weighted contribution, but we can see in the graph below why this creates an issue. Microsoft is so large (slightly more than half of the market cap in the sector) that a market cap weighting does not work well.
FIGURE 1. Companies in IGV (Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF) organized by market cap

The software index is trying to balance this by using a modified market cap weighting that limits the individual contribution of each name, which is especially important for the very large names. Looking at this in more detail (see graph below) shows the problem. The two largest companies in the index are Palantir (not covered, up \(109\%\) YTD) and Oracle (up \(44\%\) YTD), both with very strong performances this year. With Microsoft also up by more than the index (+21% vs. \(+9\%\) for the index), we can see the problem.
FIGURE 2. Companies in IGV organized by portfolio weighting

In the graph below, we show the IGV performance in comparison to an equal market cap weighted performance. We can see very clearly in the graph below, why investors have such a tough time with our space as software, on an equal basis, is actually down year to date and is underperforming the market meaningfully.
We can't change this dynamic and the IGV will get rebalanced regularly. However, it is worth keeping an eye on this phenomenon when discussing the software space.
FIGURE 3. IGV YTD performance vs. equal-market cap weighted YTD performance of companies in IGV
FIGURE 4. Price Performance Week to Date
Source: Bloomberg, Prices as of 8/28/2025. Past performance is not necessarily indicative of future results.
FIGURE 5. Price Performance Month to Date

FIGURE 6. Price Performance Year to Date

Snowflake delivered another strong beat & raise quarter against a high bar, highlighted by nearly 4pt underlying growth re- acceleration and the largest net new product revenue add in company history (S94mn). This, paired with another meaningful raise to FY product revenue above the quarterly beat level, corroborates the company's strong position in the market and supports data & analytics will continue to attract healthy budget dollars despite macro uncertainty. Commentary around Al/ML product uptake was constructive and this remains in the early innings, which paired with solid core consumption trends and visibility into 2H migrations should give investors confidence that SNOW's strength can continue in the latter half of the year. It also seems management's previous GTM performance management and refinements are leading to better execution and new logo momentum as well. The top- line outperformance also led to a solid operating margin beat and slight raise despite more S&M investments for future growth. The potential point of debate from the print was the lower than expected FCF in the quarter, but SNOW reiterated its FY guidance and noted good visibility from its schedule of contracted billings and large renewal base in 2H. Hence, there is little for bears to poke at, and we expect shares to move higher. We maintain our Overweight rating and raise our PT to \(\) 255\(from\) \ \(219\) .

Three takeaways from NCNO's Q2: (1) better Q2 revenue was driven in part by mortgage volumes for customers that have moved to platform pricing, which is a great early proof point as \(\sim 21\%\) of the total customer base is now on platform pricing after only two quarters; (2) NCNO again is keeping the ACV guide unchanged despite higher revenue, which in our view suggests there is still further conservatism in numbers - subscription revenue has tough companies in 2H; (3) NCNO landing more reference customers in Europe, which is a key growth area, and the prospect for adopting Banking Advisor is encouraging customers to renew early on platform pricing, which is another reason why the \(21\%\) mix is larger than we expected.

Okta's 2Q results and FY26 guides were pretty clean for three reasons: (1) 2Q cRPO growth was in- line with our upside scenario, driven by the public sector including the large DoD deal we picked up - it was also good to see NRR stabilize at \(106\%\) , which should continue to stabilize/ improve in 2H26 as COVID- era churn abates; (2) the additional macro and Fed risk that OKTA originally embedded in FY26 guide is now being lifted as those fears are proving to be overblown - looking forward, we continue to see an upside scenario of \(\sim 12\%\) for 4Q26 cRPO growth given the tougher compare (recall 4Q25 was a very strong bookings quarter); (3) separately, remember that no customer represents more than \(1\%\) of total OKTA ACV/revenue (some investors fear OpenAI is churning as a customer, which helps put the risk into perspective), and framing the implications of PANW/CYBR for OKTA.

Three takeaways from VEEV's Q2: (1) billings slightly beat our estimates and revenue beat by more as Commercial continues to benefit from Crossix taking share; (2) the FY26 billings bar is going up and tipping more billings into 4Q (which is not unusual for VEEV) on mechanical items like more co- terming of contracts, but also note FY guide is going up we think from continued growth in Crossix and strength in R&D; (3) 9 top 20s are migrating to Vault CRM while 3 are

moving to Salesforce – Dreamforce will be a key week to watch for both companies' life sciences endeavors, but we note arguably VEEV may have a growing AI story with agentic AI for Vault and solutions like Nitro.

Three key takeaways from CRWD's 2Q25: (1) The most incremental point in our view is that 2H25 NNARR is expected to grow at least \(40\%\) which results in a \(22\% +\) exit rate on ARR as some portion of CCP's will come back – the debate however will continue on whether this is a \(20\%\) grower next year; (2) the main nitpick from investors is that FY26 revenue guide is only going up at the bottom end, despite the faster return to NNARR growth this year – we think this reflects the continued contra- revenue associated with partner rebates as well as prudence, though it will be important to see this relationship between ARR and revenue normalize later this year and into FY27; (3) we feel good about the long- term path to \(\) 10B\$ here with platform ARR exceeding one- third of ARR and Falcon Flex continuing to inflect - already \(\sim 10\%\) of the 1,000 customers have started to reflect.

MDB delivered close to a perfect quarter. Direct Atlas accelerated again (now \(30\%\) YoY with a record quarterly \(\) add), self- service accelerated due to better execution and even the non- Atlas side grew meaningfully better than feared \((+8\%)\) vs. guidance for a high single- digit % decline). The better top- line was also reflected in better profitability and much better FCF. In other words, investors will struggle to find reasons not to revisit the name. Compared to previous quarters, management provided very similar answers with regards to the ongoing genAI debate and competition (Postgres). However, we sense with better results that investors will have an easier time agreeing here. Shares were not expensive before today (6x EV/Sales) and hence, we expect a strong share price reaction and are raising our price target to \(\) 305\(from\) \ \(270\) on a 1x higher EV/Sales multiple.

We wanted to flag the international tiering announcement from Adobe for CC All apps which some investors may have missed, and have two points: (1) the tiering plan went into effect for international customers on August 1st - the higher tier represents \(16 - 17\%\) increase and the lower tier represents an \(8\%\) discount to CC All Apps; (2) we now estimate the combined NA and International Opportunity for Adobe is \(\) 500M\(in ARR - this could be smaller or larger based on our assumptions.

In our twelfth quarterly database industry review, we detail database technology trends from the recently released 2025 Stack Overflow Developer Survey. We previously discussed takeaways from the survey from an AI perspective in our AI Weekly (see rAlmo's AI Newsletter #72, 8/4/25), and see the survey as also useful for understanding database momentum in the market given the large sample size of developers ( \(\sim 49k\) participants) with significant coding experience ( \(65\%\) of respondents have \(>10\) years coding experience). Interestingly, results show the greatest popularity for PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite, Microsoft SQL Server, Redis and MongoDB, with Elasticsearch, Oracle, BigQuery, Snowflake and Databricks also showing up materially. Redis, PostgreSQL and MariaDB showed the largest gains y/y in popularity. We also look at the gap between actual and desired adoption, which could indicate future demand, but
also grounds hype around emerging technologies. Here, results for Valkey, DuckDB, Clickhouse, Supabase, and Neo4J showed the largest gaps, respectively.

This week, we look at the MIT "State of Al in Business" report. While the report did not screen positively for overall Al investment (more specifically task- specific Al), we are encouraged by the growing importance highlighted around Al agents from incumbent vendors (CRM, NOW). MIT NANDA released its "State of Al in Business 2025" report last month (here), and was cited by multiple news outlets as potentially being the reason for the lag in tech stocks last week. The readthroughs from the report are interesting, in our view, with the most prominent takeaway surrounding the high investment levels from enterprises into GenAI, but the low realized returns from adoption thus far. Below, we walk through what we believe to be the most important datapoints in the report and analyze what they mean for the larger software space.

Microsoft is arguably the leader in the cloud services market with Windows Azure and Office 365. It can drive better earnings growth as it transitions its on-premise install bases (Office and Windows Server) to its cloud platforms.

**Upside case** USD 700.00
Adoption of Office 365 and Azure could be faster than we expect, pushing the multiple higher. Device sales could exceed expectations, leading to revenue surprises.

**Downside case** USD 470.00
The transition to cloud services may not happen fast enough, causing revenue to miss estimates as the on-premise franchises (Windows, Office, Windows Server) erode.
**Upside/Downside scenarios**

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
**Positive** - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
**Neutral** - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
**Negative** - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: We apply a 54x CY26E EV/EBIT multiple to our EBIT estimate of \(\) 2.05bn\(to arrive at our PT of\) \ \(140\) . As part of our EV build, we assume 2026E net debt of \(\) 29.8bn\$

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks to our investment thesis include increasing competition across the Al- optimized laaS space, inhibiting both existing customer growth as well as new customer contribution. With new players building out full functionality for Al- laaS, CoreWeave's market leading position could be challenged. Additionally, critical customers like Microsoft, which are also building competing solutions, could bring more of their Al laaS in house, which would have an impact on CoreWeave's growth outlook on a go forward. Lastly, any impact to the global supply chain as a result of uncertainty could result in timing delays for CoreWeaves CapEx, which would inhibit the company's ability to build out infrastructure for customers on a go forward.

Valuation Methodology: Our PT of \(\) 625\(is based on P/E multiple of 38x and CY26E EPS of\) \ \(16.65\)

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The emergence of cloud computing, virtualization and new non- PC form factors such as tablets and smart phones represent ongoing risks to Microsoft's business model and underlying profitability. Increased investment spend in long- term growth initiatives such as search and mobile could also cause margins to come under significant pressure.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
